question_text: What is the chemical formula for water?

Which element has the atomic symbol 'K'?

Which type of radiation is stopped by a thick sheet of lead?

Which process is used to remove impurities from crude oil?

Why do ionic compounds generally have high melting and boiling points?

options.A: Because they are made of small molecules
options.C: Due to strong electrostatic forces between oppositely charged ions

question_text: A solution contains 20 g of NaOH in 500 mL of solution. Calculate the molarity of the solution. (Atomic mass: Na=23, O=16, H=1)
Which of the following best explains Le Chatelier's Principle?

options.A: A system at equilibrium remains unaffected by external changes.
options.B: The rate of reaction is proportional to the concentration of products.
options.C: A system at equilibrium shifts to oppose any change imposed on it.
options.D: Only pressure changes affect chemical equilibrium.

question_text: Which statement correctly distinguishes between oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer?

options.A: Oxidation is gain of electrons, reduction is loss of electrons
options.B: Both oxidation and reduction involve loss of electrons
options.C: Oxidation is loss of electrons, reduction is gain of electrons
options.D: Oxidation and reduction do not involve electron transfer

question_text: What is the electronic configuration of Calcium (atomic number 20), and what does it indicate about its position in the periodic table?
Which of the following represents the balanced equation and optimal conditions for the industrial preparation of ammonia (Haber's process)?

options.B: N₂ + H₂ → NH₃; 400°C, 200 atm, platinum catalyst

question_text: Which of the following best defines a buffer solution and its function?

options.A: A solution that changes pH easily; example: NaCl
options.B: A solution that resists changes in pH upon dilution only; example: H₂SO₄
options.C: A solution that resists changes in pH when small amounts of acid or base are added; example: CH₃COOH + CH₃COONa
options.D: A solution that increases pH on adding acid; example: HCl

question_text: Which of the following correctly describes sp³ hybridisation in methane (CH₄)?

options.A: One s and two p orbitals mix to form three hybrid orbitals
options.B: One s and three p orbitals mix to form four equivalent hybrid orbitals arranged tetrahedrally
options.C: Methane has planar structure due to sp² hybridisation
options.D: sp³ hybridisation forms a linear molecule

question_text: Calculate the volume occupied by 1.6 g of methane (CH4) at STP. (Molar volume at STP = 22.4 L/mol, Atomic masses: C=12, H=1)
Which of the following correctly differentiates between sigma (σ) and pi (π) bonds?

options.A: Sigma bonds are weaker and formed by sidewise overlap; pi bonds are stronger and formed by head-on overlap
options.B: Sigma bonds are formed by head-on overlap; pi bonds are formed by sidewise overlap
options.C: Sigma bonds only occur in double bonds; pi bonds occur in single bonds
options.D: Both sigma and pi bonds have the same strength and overlap

question_text: Why is diamond hard and an electrical insulator, while graphite is soft and a good electrical conductor?

options.A: Diamond has metallic bonds; graphite has ionic bonds
options.B: Diamond has layered structure; graphite has tetrahedral structure
options.C: Diamond has strong covalent bonds in 3D; graphite has delocalized electrons in layers
options.D: Both have similar bonding but different crystal sizes

question_text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of steps in the Contact Process for manufacturing sulphuric acid?

options.A: Combustion of SO₂ → Absorption in water → Oxidation to SO₃
options.B: Burning S → Oxidation of SO₂ to SO₃ → Absorption of SO₃ in water or H₂SO₄
options.C: Electrolysis of H₂SO₄ → Oxidation of SO₃ → Collection
options.D: Dissolution of SO₂ in acid → Neutralization with base → Oxidation

question_text: Which statement correctly describes the working of a Daniell cell?

options.A: Zinc is reduced and copper is oxidized, producing current
options.B: Electrons flow from copper to zinc through the wire
options.C: Zinc is oxidized at the anode and copper is reduced at the cathode
options.D: The salt bridge blocks electron flow between half-cells

question_text: Which of the following best describes the trend of effective nuclear charge (Z_eff) in the periodic table?

options.A: Z_eff decreases across a period and increases down a group
options.B: Z_eff increases across a period and decreases down a group
options.C: Z_eff remains constant in a period and a group
options.D: Z_eff decreases across a period and remains constant down a group

question_text: What is electronegativity and how does it vary in the periodic table?

options.A: It is the energy required to remove an electron; increases down a group
options.B: It is the tendency to lose electrons; decreases across a period
options.C: It is the tendency to attract bonding electrons; increases across a period and decreases down a group
options.D: It is the energy to gain an electron; constant across a period

question_text: A first-order reaction has a half-life of 20 minutes. Calculate the time required for 75% completion of the reaction.
What is molarity and molality? Discuss their dependence on temperature.
Which of the following best describes the common ion effect?

options.A: Decrease in solubility of a salt by adding a solution with a common ion
options.B: Increase in solubility of salt with the same ion
options.C: Effect caused only by heating the solution
options.D: A reaction that involves no ions

question_text: Which statement correctly describes the preparation of ethanol from ethene?

options.A: Ethene reacts with water in the presence of H₂SO₄ at 300°C and 60 atm
options.C: Ethene is treated with NaOH at room temperature
options.D: Ethene reacts with Cl₂ in sunlight

question_text:
Which of the following shows correct conversions?
(a) Ethanol to Ethene
(b) Ethanoic acid to Ethane

options.A:
(a) Dehydration using conc. H₂SO₄
(b) Reduction using NaBH₄
options.B:
(a) Oxidation using KMnO₄
(b) Reduction using H₂/Ni
options.C:
(a) Dehydration using conc. H₂SO₄
(b) Reduction using Na + H₂O
options.D:
(a) Hydration using H₂O
(b) Substitution using NaOH

question_text: How are primary, secondary, and tertiary alcohols distinguished using Victor Meyer's method?

options.A: By their color in litmus test
options.C: By producing different colored compounds (red, blue, no color)

question_text: Which of the following best defines isomerism and gives examples of structural isomers?

options.A: Same molecular formula, same structure — CH₃OH and C₂H₅OH
options.B: Same structure but different boiling points — CH₄ and CH₃OH
options.C: Same molecular formula, different structural arrangement — C₄H₁₀ (n-butane and isobutane)

question_text: What does Faraday's First Law of Electrolysis state?

options.A: The amount of substance deposited is independent of charge
options.B: The amount of substance deposited is proportional to the volume of solution
options.C: The amount of substance deposited is proportional to the charge passed
options.D: No substance is deposited in electrolysis

question_text: A student titrates 25 mL of an unknown HCl solution with 0.1 M NaOH solution. If 20 mL of NaOH is required to reach the endpoint, calculate the molarity of the HCl solution.
Describe the process of refining copper by electrolytic method.

options.A: Copper is refined by heating with charcoal to remove impurities.
options.B: Copper is refined by dissolving impure copper in acid and electroplating.
options.C: Impure copper acts as anode and pure copper as cathode in electrolytic cell; copper ions deposit on cathode while impurities fall off.
options.D: Copper is refined by mixing with zinc and heating to form brass.

question_text: Explain why transition metals exhibit variable oxidation states and form colored compounds.

options.A: Due to incomplete filling of inner d-orbitals and involvement of different numbers of electrons in bonding.
options.C: Due to the presence of only one oxidation state.
options.D: Because they form ionic compounds only.

question_text: What is a covalent bond? Explain the formation of a nitrogen molecule ($\text{N}_2$) using Lewis dot structure.

options.A: A covalent bond is formed by sharing of electrons; nitrogen shares three pairs of electrons forming a triple bond.
options.B: A covalent bond is formed by transfer of electrons.
options.C: A covalent bond is formed by ionic attraction.
options.D: A covalent bond is formed by sharing of protons.

question_text: Define ionization energy. How does it vary across a period and down a group in the periodic table?

options.A: Ionization energy is the energy required to remove an electron; it increases across a period and decreases down a group.
options.B: Ionization energy decreases across a period and increases down a group.
options.C: Ionization energy remains constant across periods and groups.
options.D: Ionization energy is unrelated to electron removal.

question_text: What is the role of cryolite in the electrolytic extraction of aluminium?

options.A: Cryolite increases the melting point of aluminium oxide.
options.B: Cryolite acts as a flux, lowering the melting point of alumina to reduce energy consumption.
options.C: Cryolite reacts with aluminium to form an alloy.
options.D: Cryolite prevents the formation of impurities.

question_text: Explain the difference between saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons with examples.

options.A: Saturated hydrocarbons have single bonds only; e.g., methane. Unsaturated hydrocarbons have double or triple bonds; e.g., ethene, ethyne.
options.B: Saturated hydrocarbons have double bonds; unsaturated have single bonds.
options.C: Saturated hydrocarbons are aromatic; unsaturated are aliphatic.
options.D: Saturated hydrocarbons contain oxygen; unsaturated do not.

question_text: Calculate the pH of a 0.001 M HCl solution.
State the law of mass action.

options.A: Forward and reverse rates are equal at equilibrium.
options.B: Concentration ratio of products to reactants is constant at equilibrium.
options.C: Reactants and products have equal concentration at equilibrium.

question_text: Describe the main steps involved in the manufacture of cement.

options.A: Mixing of limestone and clay, heating in a kiln, grinding to powder, and adding gypsum.
options.B: Crushing of sand, mixing with water, and drying.
options.C: Melting of cement materials and casting into blocks.
options.D: Mixing of lime and sand without heating.

question_text: Explain the concept of resonance with respect to the benzene molecule.

options.A: Resonance is the delocalization of electrons over alternate bonds, making benzene more stable than any one structure.
options.B: Resonance is the rapid interconversion of benzene with other hydrocarbons.
options.C: Resonance means benzene has only single bonds.
options.D: Resonance refers to the vibration of benzene molecules.

question_text: Write the balanced chemical equation for the reaction of ethanol with sodium metal and name the products.

options.A: 2C2H5OH + 2Na → 2C2H5ONa + H2; products are sodium ethoxide and hydrogen gas.
options.B: C2H5OH + NaCl → C2H5Cl + NaOH; products are ethyl chloride and sodium hydroxide.
options.C: C2H5OH + Na → C2H5H + NaOH; products are ethane and sodium hydroxide.
options.D: C2H5OH + O2 → CO2 + H2O; products are carbon dioxide and water.

question_text: How does an increase in temperature affect the rate of a chemical reaction? Explain using collision theory.

options.A: Increasing temperature increases kinetic energy, causing more frequent and energetic collisions, thus increasing reaction rate.
options.B: Increasing temperature decreases particle movement and reduces reaction rate.
options.C: Temperature has no effect on reaction rate.
options.D: Increasing temperature decreases the number of collisions.

question_text: Differentiate between an ideal solution and a non-ideal solution.

options.A: Ideal solutions follow Raoult's law exactly; non-ideal solutions deviate due to intermolecular interactions.
options.B: Ideal solutions have a fixed boiling point; non-ideal solutions boil at variable temperatures.
options.C: Ideal solutions contain only one component; non-ideal have many.
options.D: Ideal solutions do not mix; non-ideal solutions mix completely.

question_text: Explain why metals are good conductors of electricity.

options.A: Because of the presence of free-moving valence electrons that carry charge.
options.B: Because metals have tightly bound electrons.
options.C: Because metals have ionic bonds that allow electron flow.

question_text: What is radioactivity?

options.A: Emission of particles from unstable nuclei.

question_text: Describe the main principles of modern periodic law.

options.A: Properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic numbers.
options.B: Elements are arranged by increasing atomic mass.
options.C: Elements are grouped by their discovery date.

question_text:
Write the IUPAC names for the following compounds:
(a) CH3CH2COOH
(b) CH3COCH3
Explain why pure water does not conduct electricity, but tap water does.

options.A: Pure water lacks ions; tap water contains dissolved salts that provide ions for conduction.
options.B: Pure water has many ions; tap water does not.
options.C: Pure water is acidic; tap water is basic.
options.D: Pure water is a conductor; tap water is an insulator.

question_text: What are allotropes?

options.A: Different forms of the same element.

question_text: Describe the laboratory preparation of hydrogen gas.

options.A: Reacting zinc with dilute sulfuric acid produces hydrogen gas.
options.C: Electrolysis of salt water produces hydrogen gas.
options.D: Combustion of hydrogen produces hydrogen gas.

question_text: A sample of gas occupies 10 L at 27°C and 750 mmHg pressure. What will be its volume at STP?
Differentiate between an orbit and an orbital.

options.A: Orbit is a fixed path of electrons; orbital is a region with high probability of finding an electron.
options.B: Orbit is a region; orbital is a fixed path.
options.D: Orbit relates to protons; orbital relates to electrons.

question_text: Why is concentrated sulphuric acid used as a dehydrating agent?

options.A: Because it reacts to form water.
options.B: Because it absorbs water and removes it from substances.
options.C: Because it dilutes quickly in water.
options.D: Because it is a strong acid only.

question_text: What is Hess's Law of Constant Heat Summation?

options.B: Heat change depends on reaction path.
options.C: Total enthalpy change is the same regardless of reaction path.

question_text: What is the integrated rate law for a first-order reaction?
Calculate the vapor pressure of a glucose solution given: 18g glucose in 100g water; vapor pressure of pure water at 293 K = 17.535 mm Hg.
What is the relationship between pH and pOH at 25°C?
Which statement correctly describes the SN1 reaction?

options.A: Bimolecular, no intermediate, inversion of configuration.
options.B: Unimolecular, involves carbocation intermediate, racemization occurs.

question_text: Calculate standard cell potential (E°cell) for: Zn(s) + Cu²⁺(aq) → Zn²⁺(aq) + Cu(s); E°Zn²⁺/Zn = -0.76 V, E°Cu²⁺/Cu = +0.34 V. Is reaction spontaneous?
What does Ostwald's dilution law explain?

options.A: Relation between boiling point and pressure.
options.B: Relation between ionic radius and charge.
options.C: Relation between degree of dissociation and concentration of weak electrolytes.

question_text: Hydrogen bonding affects the physical properties of water by:

options.C: Increasing boiling point and surface tension.

question_text: What causes real gases to deviate from ideal behavior?

options.D: Intermolecular forces and finite molecular volume.

question_text: Williamson's synthesis is used to prepare:
Calculate mole fraction of urea in 10% (w/w) aqueous solution (molar mass = 60 g/mol).
Activation energy is:

options.D: Minimum energy needed for reaction to occur.

question_text: Second law of thermodynamics states:

options.C: Entropy of an isolated system always increases.

question_text: Which is a type of isomerism in coordination compounds?
Calculate freezing point depression for 1.0 g solute (molar mass 100 g/mol) in 50 g water (Kf=1.86 K kg/mol).
Which reaction involves aldol condensation?

options.C: Two aldehydes/ketones combine forming β-hydroxy aldehyde/ketone.

question_text: Explain the principles and applications of acid-base volumetric titration.

options.A: Determining solution concentration by neutralization; used in quality control.
options.B: Measuring boiling points of acids and bases.
options.C: Calculating molar mass from titration volume.
options.D: Using indicators to change solution color permanently.

question_text: State Kohlrausch's Law of independent ion migration with explanation.

options.A: Total conductivity is sum of individual ion conductivities at infinite dilution.
options.B: All ions migrate at the same speed in an electric field.
options.C: Conductivity depends only on ion concentration.
options.D: Ion migration causes no change in solution resistance.

question_text: Outline methods to prepare aniline from nitrobenzene.

options.B: Catalytic reduction using tin and hydrochloric acid.

question_text: Define lattice energy and explain the Born-Haber cycle for NaCl formation.

options.A: Energy released when ions form lattice; Born-Haber cycle is energy balance for ionic compound formation.
options.B: Energy absorbed to break ionic bonds.

question_text: Discuss factors affecting gas solubility in liquids.

options.A: Pressure, temperature, and nature of gas and solvent.
options.C: Volume and density are main factors.
options.D: Solubility is constant for all gases.

question_text: Derive the relation between standard Gibbs free energy change and equilibrium constant.
Explain Schottky and Frenkel defects with examples.

options.A: Schottky: vacancy defects; Frenkel: ion displaced to interstitial site.

question_text: Describe benzoic acid preparation from toluene and electrophilic substitution mechanism in benzene.

options.A: Oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid; substitution involves carbocation intermediate.

question_text: Write cell reactions, calculate EMF, and cell notation for Ag/Ag+ and Zn/Zn2+ voltaic cell. (Given $E^\circ_{\text{Ag}^+/\text{Ag}}=+0.80V$, $E^\circ_{\text{Zn}^{2+}/\text{Zn}}=-0.76V$)

options.A: EMF = 1.56 V; Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻; Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag; Cell notation Zn|Zn²⁺||Ag⁺|Ag
options.B: EMF = 0.04 V; Ag oxidation; Zn reduction.
options.C: EMF = 1.56 V; Ag oxidation; Zn reduction.
options.D: EMF = 0.76 V; Zn and Ag react directly.

question_text: How is ozone depleted in the stratosphere? What are the effects?

options.A: By CFCs releasing Cl radicals; causes increased UV radiation.
options.B: By water vapor absorption; no effect.
options.C: By oxygen molecules only; causes acid rain.
options.D: By methane release; causes global warming.

question_text: Explain van der Waals forces and their effect on boiling points.

options.A: Weak intermolecular forces; higher forces raise boiling points.
options.B: Strong ionic bonds; lower boiling points.
options.D: Van der Waals forces break covalent bonds.

question_text: Describe DNA and RNA structure; explain protein primary, secondary, and tertiary structures.

options.A: DNA double helix; RNA single strand; proteins fold into 3D shapes.
options.B: DNA single strand; RNA double helix; proteins linear only.
options.C: Both DNA and RNA are proteins.

question_text:
Write notes with examples on:
(a) Kolbe's Reaction
(b) Reimer-Tiemann Reaction
(c) Wurtz Reaction

options.A: Kolbe's: Electrolysis of sodium salt; Reimer-Tiemann: formylation of phenols; Wurtz: coupling of alkyl halides.
options.B: Kolbe's: Oxidation; Reimer-Tiemann: reduction; Wurtz: substitution.

question_text: Calculate the normality of a solution containing 4.9 g of H2SO4 dissolved in 250 mL of solution. (Atomic masses: H=1, S=32, O=16)
Calculate the molarity of a solution prepared by dissolving 11.7 g of NaOH in 500 mL of solution. (Atomic masses: Na=23, O=16, H=1)
Calculate the percentage composition of oxygen in potassium chlorate (KClO3). (Atomic masses: K=39, Cl=35.5, O=16)
Calculate the volume of CO2 gas at STP produced when 10 g of calcium carbonate decomposes. (Atomic masses: Ca=40, C=12, O=16; Molar volume at STP = 22.4 L)
Determine the empirical formula of a compound containing 40% carbon, 6.7% hydrogen, and 53.3% oxygen by mass.
Calculate the molar mass of a gas if 2.5 g occupies 1.12 L at STP. (Molar volume at STP = 22.4 L)
Calculate the molarity of sulfuric acid solution if 25 mL of it neutralizes 30 mL of 0.2 M NaOH.
Calculate the enthalpy change (ΔH) for the combustion of 2 moles of methane, given ΔHf°(CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol, ΔHf°(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol, ΔHf°(CH4) = -74.8 kJ/mol.
Determine the volume of oxygen gas (at STP) required to completely react with 5 g of propane (C3H8). (Molar mass C=12, H=1; Molar volume = 22.4 L)
Calculate the degree of dissociation of acetic acid if a 0.1 M solution has conductivity of 1.28 × 10⁻³ S cm⁻¹. Molar conductivity at infinite dilution = 390 S cm² mol⁻¹.
Calculate the pH of a solution prepared by mixing 50 mL of 0.1 M HCl and 50 mL of 0.1 M NaOH.
Calculate the equilibrium constant (Kc) for the reaction N2 + 3H2 ⇌ 2NH3 at 500 K if ΔG° = -33 kJ/mol.
Calculate the boiling point elevation of a solution containing 2 moles of a non-volatile solute in 500 g of water. (Kb for water = 0.52 K kg/mol)
Calculate the pH of a 0.01 M solution of a weak acid with Ka = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵.
Calculate the standard cell potential for the reaction: Zn + 2H⁺ → Zn²⁺ + H₂, given E°(Zn²⁺/Zn) = -0.76 V and E°(H⁺/H₂) = 0.00 V.
Derive the integrated rate law for a second-order reaction and interpret the meaning of its rate constant.

options.A: 1/[A] = kt + 1/[A]₀; k indicates reaction speed with units L mol⁻¹ s⁻¹
options.D: Rate is independent of concentration; k is unitless

question_text: Explain the van't Hoff equation derivation
Derive the general relation between equilibrium constants Kp and Kc for gaseous reactions.
Derive the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation for buffer solutions.
Derive the Nernst equation relating electrode potential to ion concentration.

options.A: E = E° - (RT/nF) ln Q; electrode potential depends on reaction quotient
options.D: E = E° only; no concentration dependence

question_text: Derive the Clausius-Clapeyron equation and explain its application to calculate enthalpy of vaporization.

options.A: ln P = -ΔHvap/RT + C; relates vapor pressure to temperature

question_text: Derive the formula relating the rate constant of a first-order reaction to its half-life.
A reaction has a rate constant k = 2.3 x 10^-5 s^-1. What is its order of reaction?

options.D: Cannot be determined from units alone

question_text: Why does a rise in temperature increase the rate of an exothermic reaction, even though it shifts equilibrium towards reactants?

options.C: It increases the number of effective collisions.

question_text: What is the primary role of concentrated H2SO4 in the esterification reaction?
Which of the following noble gases is known to form compounds, thus deviating from the octet rule?
If a solution has a pH of 9 at 25 degrees Celsius, what is its pOH?
What is the primary reason transition metals exhibit variable oxidation states?

options.C: Involvement of both (n-1)d and ns electrons

question_text: What is the major product when propene reacts with HBr in the presence of a peroxide?

Which type of solid is characterized by very high melting points, hardness, and electrical insulation due to strong covalent bonds extending throughout the entire structure?
What is the hybridization of the carbon atom in a carbonyl group (C=O)?
In the Haber process, N2(g) + 3H2(g) <=> 2NH3(g), what happens to the equilibrium if the pressure is increased?
Explain why H2O is a liquid at room temperature while H2S is a gas, despite sulfur being below oxygen in the periodic table.

options.A: H2S has stronger London dispersion forces.
options.D: H2S has a higher molar mass.

question_text: Which of the following organic compounds is the most acidic?

options.B: Presence of lone pair on nitrogen
options.C: Availability of lone pair and stability of conjugate acid

What is the catalyst commonly used in the industrial hydrogenation of vegetable oils to produce vegetable ghee?
What is the oxidation state of sulfur in H2SO4?
Why is phenol more acidic than ethanol?

options.A: Due to inductive effect of benzene ring
options.B: Due to resonance stabilization of phenoxide ion
options.C: Due to stronger hydrogen bonding in phenol

question_text: Which colligative property is most commonly used to determine the molar mass of macromolecules like proteins and polymers due to its significant magnitude at room temperature?
Which named reaction involves the conversion of an aldehyde or ketone into an imine using a primary amine?
How many d-electrons are present in Fe3+ ion? (Atomic number of Fe = 26)
Which type of intermolecular forces are dominant in non-polar molecules like CH4?
What is the byproduct formed along with soap during the saponification reaction (hydrolysis of fat/oil with alkali)?
Which of the following factors does NOT affect the rate of a chemical reaction?

options.D: Overall Gibbs Free Energy Change of reaction

question_text: If the standard reduction potential of an electrode is positive, what does it signify about the tendency of the species to get reduced?
Which of the following is a zwitterionic compound?
What is the common name for the reaction where an aldehyde with no alpha-hydrogen undergoes self-oxidation and reduction?
Why do aqueous solutions of transition metal ions often appear colored?
Which of the following is a strong electrolyte?
What is the general formula for a saturated cyclic hydrocarbon?
Which noble gas is used in fluorescent lights and advertising signs?
What is the major product when benzene reacts with methyl chloride in the presence of anhydrous AlCl3?
According to VSEPR theory, what is the electron domain geometry around the central atom in an SF6 molecule?
